newsitem.title: SPAIN: Spanish peseta braked by intervention fears.
newsitem.headline: Spanish peseta braked by intervention fears.

text.p: Fear of intervention by the Bank of Spain is braking the peseta rise against the mark, dealers said on Wednesday.
"If there were no fears of intervention by the Bank of Spain the peseta would have risen more," a dealer said.
The peseta was supported in morning trade by US dollar and Italian lira strength, but still remained largely rangebound.
At 1550 GMT the Spanish currency was trading at around 84.08/11 against the mark versus a closing level yesterday at 84.10/11.
In recent months the Bank of Spain has intervened, selling pesetas against the mark, every time the Spanish currency attempted to break the 84.00 level.
Spanish currency reserves rose $1.64 billion in December to $61.82. This compares to $38.23 billion in December in 1995.
The Bank of Spain does not normally comment on intervention.
